You, Sarah Palin; You, Charles Grassley will have to deal with this issue with a relative one day. I take that back, Mr. Grassley, I'm sure your wife or female relatives will deal for this in your manly stead.
Respite saves money.  Out-of-home placements are ridiculously expensive.  Respite keeps people at home, where they and their families want them to be, and saves us all tons of money!

There are lots more of us out here in Mr. Ogg's situation...needing lots of time consuming, expensive, and needed personal care...I'm 32 now and have lived with a somewhat high level spinal cord injury since I was 17...fortunately my family helps me with daily needs for now, but just how to meet my costly long term care needs weighs heavily on my mind.

Yesterday, I was shocked and depressed to learn that CMS (Medicare) has decided not to pay for discussions with patients about prognosis and planning end of life care. I cannot imagine a legitimate justification for this recission. Patients and families are eager for this information, and it is important to them that it be available. Most want to understand their conditions and the options available to them. It is also invaluable to their physicians and other health care providers to know and understand their preferences. None of us want to cause unnecessary discomfort nor, for that matter, would we want to experience it ourselves. I can think of no reason why this option to be informed and participate in decisions should not be provided to those who want it. One could argue that it should not require financial incentives to accomplish this, but we live in a fee for service environment and there is no doubt that providing a fee will likely encourage the service.

Indeed, it is unethical and contrary to our Hippocratic Oath not to ask patients and their families what they would want to have done at all stages of illness. We all obtain "informed consent" and discuss alternative options before tests and procedures. End of life care should be no different. What if not having such discussions, with resulting unnecessary pain and suffering for the patient and unnecessary costs to the family were considered grounds for malpractice? Perhaps that would encourage practitioners to have these discussions without payment. But this is not a financial problem but rather a human one.

Speaking as a heart failure specialist who has worked with many patients with this chronic condition, there is a wide spectrum of potential management approaches for patients with severe heart failure who have not responded to optimal treatment regimens. These range from experimental drugs to device implantation, mechanical assist devices, and transplantation. These patients face many important choices that that should involve patients and their families.

In my view, this recision of support for meaningful end of life discussions reflects a lack of courage on the part of those responsible, and they should be very ashamed of themselves. In short, appropriate and ethical decisions have been defeated by dishonest sound bites (e.g., "death panels") and a lack of courage by our leaders. For this, everyone (patients, families, medical personnel who will have to participate in patients' unnecessary suffering, and the public which will have to ultimately pay for the exorbitant costs of end of life care) will suffer.

The grotesque military budgets in this country are A) an enormous works project for the military-industrial complex, and B) and enormous jobs program. If we can't manage to make real reductions in a time of extreme fiscal crisis then there is a much deeper problem going on in this nation. That problem is the complete inability on the part of the American people to see where we are now as a nation, not where we were 50 years ago. What will result from our great national delusion is a collapse of American living standards and power in the world...a la the British Empire and the Soviet Union

Weapons programs should not be a target for cuts. Troop numbers don't determine the future of our military; we can get troops quickly if needed. Weapons programs, which sometimes span more than a decade, cannot be picked back up once they are abandoned. Technology is the key to keeping our military power, and we cannot abandon it to short term budget concerns. It would be far better to take all troops out of Europe and Japan than to abandon our weapons programs.

If the rate of unemployment ever drops below 6 percent, we should cut the defense budget in half.

The military-industrial complex has been devouring our economy since 1945.

Well it's about time that someone in Washington woke up and realized that the Defense Department has been getting way too much money for quite a few years. Just think of how much money could have been spent on our educational system or on funding the tax cuts for the wealthy had we not gone into Iraq. What a waste of money the Iraq War was! And for that fact, we're wasting way too much of our tax dollars on Afghanistan; because when we finally leave there, that country will go back to the way it was before we went into it shortly after 9/11. What a sad commentary of our efforts to bring something good to that country.

Personally I think that the Defense Department budget needs to be trimmed more than just $100 billion over a five year period. No Tricare health insurance premium increases since 1995? Yikes! Sorry military retirees, but I agree with Gates. You need to pay more of your fair share of those premiums. After all, your peers in State governments (and other pension plans) across the U.S. pay their fair share of health insurance premiums. And they've worked just as many years for those benefits as you have.

One of the biggest cuts in the Defense budget, though, could come as a result of finding other, far less expensive and more reliable contractors to replace contractors who work for Halliburtin.

Yes, it is long past time to trim the Defense budget. Let the trimming begin!

Go Packers! People will see how overrated vick and the eagles are.

Ugh, Rex, I like the bravado but sometimes it's better to just keep your mouth shut. All you're doing is playing into Brady and Belichick's hands. And that's in the admittedly unlikely chance that you can solve your Manning problems.

As a Patriots fan, yes it's annoying but there is nothing Rex Ryan can do or say to detract from Brady's success. He'll be the MVP and has a good chance at a fourth ring this year. But I think there is a method to Ryan's madness: his childish statements draw attention to him and thus allow his players and coaches to focus on what they need to do week-to-week without too much media interference. Ryan knows what he said is untrue (if Belichick's system is so great, logically that means you'd have to study it extensively) but it has a purpose.

Here’s the situation that Elway now owns: the defense is burned to crisp, they just fired the architect of their esoteric half cooked offense, and all the guys that created this disaster are still in the saddle.

Elway’s immediate subordinate, General Manager Brian Xanders, is described in the Denver Press as a salary cap specialist, not a talent evaluator. One might think that “capology” is a pretty narrow specialty, more suited to an “Assistant” GM, but while Xanders sits in the chair, the Broncos can’t offer it to a roster guy.

So who’s going to turn around the barrel scraping Denver defense? The Denver Post today has “most of the college scouting and pro scouting staff remaining with the team.” So, apparently there’s no plan to make a major hire for Director of Player Personnel.

How does this franchise look to a top coaching prospect? You have the ailing owner, the discredited management team, a local sports Super Hero, and then--to top it all off--you’ve got Tebow. This is a great gig for a Head Coach who plays russian roulette to relax.

The Bronco have turned into a bad performance art explication of The Peter Principle, and the only way Elway is going to turn it around is if he can hire a real General Manager and empower him to build a roster. You can't spin it: no roster, no wins.

As a retired civilian in the U.S. military whose last posting was a deployment in one of the toughest parts of Afghanistan nicknamed "Rocket City," I witnesses countless wasteful practices and gross fund mismanagement. Defined broadly, our military is basically a U.S. Department of Welfare that outdoes all other bureaucracy or departments in the U.S. government. Defense contractors with security clearance make way too much money for doing similar types of jobs without secret, TS, TS/SCI, etc., whatever those alphabet soup designations call. The salary of an American citizen interpreter with a foreign language extremely in demand is $200k a year. The whole business of security clearance is a sham. These include outrageous costs of investigating background check and granting security clearance. Local media once reported the Pentagon itself as a “theft central,” given those people walking in and out of the building and its annexes with all types of security clearance.

In addition to proposed budget cuts and program eliminations already mentioned by other commentators, I would like to point out operating expense on lifetime healthcare coverage, access to subsidized grocery stores, PX and commissaries; highly discriminating Officers' associations; vacation clubs; gyms; childcare facilities; DOD schools; free or heavily discounted air travel, lodging and accommodation, among others. If a company were to provide all of these fringe benefits to its employees and their dependents, that company would not be able to balance the books.

To personify the military, this person has no practical life skills and lacks common economic sense, relying on others for his or her wellbeing.

Having family members who served in Vietnam War and friends who actively serve in current battlefields, I do understand about sacrifice of military personnel and families have to make and anticipation of incentives to keep everyone fed and well compensated. I was also part of it. You do have my utmost respect and gratitude. It’s not your fault that you and your dependents have all these privileges. But this country also has other mouths to feed. You have to live like the rest of us.

To echo other readers, our defense policy and budget plan need a drastic overhaul.

The cut spending/reduce the size of
government mantra, now ascendant in Texas, has been touted and bruited about by aspirant officeholders for as long as I have been following politics, which seems lately to be far too many years.

The mantra, whether from Texas, some county in Long Island or, most amusingly, from Washington, DC, has always been entirely phony, has never been followed through on, and must by now be the most debased slogan in American political history. Yet here it comes again rolling back like a plugged nickel.

The slogan (one cannot dignify it as
argument) always rings out from the
hustings as if spending exists in the
abstract, independent of all other
Government activity and obligation; and
the notion of shrinking the size of government, if anything, is discussed in even more airy and irrelevant terms by
these political tyros.

On the federal level, the size of the budget since 1950, when graphed, traces an almost perfect 45° slope from left to right, while the graph showing federal spending as a percentage of GDP shows where the real issue should be focused: on the revenue side. That's our issue.

A simple way of understanding what politicians are supposed to do may be stated this way: find out what government can rationally do to support the general welfare and then raise revenue to back these programs. But in the twilight zone of Texas and the republican-controlled Congress we can run up enormous deficits (some $820 billion the last 5 republican administrations) but do nothing to raise revenues. How, exactly, on the national level, with an aging population and the projected outlays for Medicare over the next 30 years can the government spend less? Only charlatans speak this language, while out of the other side of their craven mouths they drool on about cutting income and estate taxes for the most fortunate. Amazing and highly entertaining stuff if one wasn't an American.

Texas is a microcosm of what will happen nationally if the right-wing Republicans get their way - no new taxes, corporate ownership of government and the destruction of the social safety net. Gov. Rick Perry wants to completely opt out of the federal Medicaid program, and has no clear plan of what to replace it with. Presumably, nothing. Twenty-five percent of Texans are already uninsured.

Texas is broke in large part because it's one of only seven states with no personal income tax or state corporate tax - and the State Legislature has passed a law forbidding such a tax from ever being enacted. Perry has openly talked of secession and some proponents of independence have already discussed carving up the Republic of Texas Redux into four separate provinces.

Underneath it all, of course, is racism, particularly against Mexicans (who used to own Texas, but nobody there talks about that bothersome little factoid). I have relatives and acquaintances in Texas who claim they'd rather the state axe Medicaid than let any "illegals" get medical care. So if they want to secede, fine with me. They'll need passports to visit me, though, or they might have to climb over the border fences of Louisiana, Arkansas, Oklahoma and New Mexico and get past Homeland Security first.

I wish Molly Ivins were still around to wisecrack about the weird state of her state. But something she said about Bush when he was governor is even more aptly applied to the current occupant: "In Texas we do not hold high expectations of the office. It's mostly been occupied by crooks, dorks and the comatose."

And this gem: "It's a low tax, low service state - so shoot us. The only depressing part is that unlike Mississippi, we can afford to do better. We just don't."

I laugh whenever I hear a conservative say that lowering tax rates do not increase the deficit. I don't know what they are taking to induce such hallucinations but I wish they would share...

In their quest to create jobs by pandering to the wealthiest the conservatives have us on a path which will take us back through Banana Republic status until we reach the something which resembles the feudal system of the middle ages. An age where organized christian relgion terrorized the masses with inquisitions and crusades, and where a very small group of lords controlled all the wealth and societal power making sure the people had no say. Sounds like exactly what the pro-christian, pro-corporate conservatives believe in. Western civilization has fought many dire and bloody wars, and had many revolutions, to overthrow those tyrannical forces in the name of freedom. And the conservatives are trying to bring it all back, insultingly enough, in the name of freedom.

The main thing which will limit our freedom is the consolidation of wealth and power in the hands of the few. And it has been a very long time since the few had so much wealth and power. And conservatives in Texas, New Jersey and everywhere else across our land where they are in power are trying aid the few, to take us back in time and return the masses to the bondage of serfdom...

This dude cannot abide.

Laying off public service workers in droves will be their approach to the problem in Texas and will end up exacerbating it, as fewer dollars in the hands of working-class consumers further drives down demand and depresses the economy. Of course, the Texas braintrusts will then have to fork over the unemployment benefits they so resent.

It's a vicious circle, especially when the wealthy private sector gladly takes all the tax cuts given to it and invests that money creating businesses and jobs overseas rather than in America. They know full well they are just plundering this country, aided and abetted by their Republican tools in the congress.

Obama's big mistake was trusting that they'd do the right thing when he basically put the mega-banks on Wall Street in control of restarting the economy, rather than liquidating or nationalizing them. Their knee jerk response was to reward themselves with huge bonuses in return for stiffing Main Street. These major players in the private sector hold all the power and will only serve their own interests as long as the federal government continues to keep out of their way.

We needed FDR and we got Obama trying to ape Ronald Reagan while the GOP & the teabaggers portrayed him as the second coming of Vladimir Lenin. Alice could not have envisaged greater distortions of reality on the other side of her looking glass.

I have become reconciled to watching this train wreck with all the detachment that starvation may allow when the dollar totally collapses. The Republicans are determined not to lose their self-styled game of chicken with Obama on the debt ceiling even if it means driving their hot rod off the cliff. We'll see who's left standing on the other side of that stunt. It might not include the American middle class.

The budget problems in Texas are another reminder that our country is in an economic race to the bottom. We have tried all the usual fiscal and monetary methods in an effort to jump-start our economy again.

We have had extended tax cuts, massive deficit stimulus spending of $1.3 trillion per year, quantative easing, short-term bank interest rates of 0-.25 percent, our government buying banks bad assets, etc. But, our economy still struggles and is unable to recover. And we still have extremely high unemployment of nearly 10 percent, with no hope of much improvement for the foreseeable future.

By now, it is obvious that we are not in a normal recession. Monetary policies are not going to return our sick economy to health. We are suffering from structural economic decline, caused by sending thousands of factories and millions of jobs to China.

Most people do not realize that because of something called the multiplier effect, when a factory closes, it affects many workers who do not directly work at the factory that closed.

The multiplier effect is the ratio or number of new jobs created indirectly when a new factory opens. It varies from about 2 to 4 new jobs created for each one new worker hired directly by the factory. But, the multiplier effect also comes into play when a factory closes and moves to China. Many more workers lose their jobs when a factory closes than just the number of factory workers who were directly fired by the factory.

By sending tens of thousands of factories and millions of jobs to China and elsewhere, many more millions of American workers have lost their jobs, or had their incomes decrease, because of the multiplier effect.

This economic blight is spreading across our entire economy, with the resulting loss of tax revenue for our federal, state, and local governments. Unless we grow our economy and our tax base, our only choices are more deficit spending or cut government spending for much-needed services.

And the downward spiral will continue until our politicians take strong action and bring our factories and jobs back to America. Our factories have created an economic boom in China, while we are in an extended recession. But, our politicians do nothing.

Frank Mitchell
jobsback.com

Professor Krugman's concluding statement says it all:
" And what we’re seeing right now is a future that doesn’t work."

That sums it up very well for the nation at large and Texas is just another harbinger of what is the future of the nation as a whole. So we really have no choice at the moment but to allow the Republicans to do their best to shoot themselves in the foot/feet and then the country pick up the pieces in the elections of 2012.

The next two years will be grim and fraught with contention and conflict between the two political parties. However, the chances are very good that the Republicans will once again overreach, as they are very good at that when they come into power.

The only question is whether the electorate will come to recognize the Republican misuse of power and react accordingly by dismissing Republicans in the elections of 2012. The electorate did just that in the elections of 1998 when they reacted against the impeachment over-reaching by the House Republicans.

Just this week there was a poll that indicated that the thinking of the electorate is becoming more progressive: http://news.yahoo.com...

With any luck at all, the Republicans in the House will bring about their own demise when the electorate finally wakes up to the fact that the future as determined by the Republicans is not a viable course of action for our future well-being. Better late than never.

Dr. Krugman's comments are spot-on, except there seems to be great confusion as to whether we are $20 billion, $25 billion, or even $30 billion in the hole. No one knows for sure, but I think we are about to find out the hard way once they go to the bank to cash their paycheck.

The state did not escape the recession, but we have experienced a delayed impact due to many of the reasons cited in the column. Many of us know people who have lost jobs and struggled to replace their income with the new jobs being created, and recent headlines in the local papers have shown an increase in foreclosures showing up in our largest growth areas recently.

The stories of repeated requests to cut budgets at every state agency, including prisons (that is a serious sign here in death row valley) and universities only netted a couple of billion. The GOP and "Good Hair" Governor Perry have sworn to not raise taxes and to cut the fat from a government their party has run exclusively for over a decade, yet they were successful in getting a majority in both houses of the legislature along with the re-election of GWB's successor. They have a lot of smoke and mirrors on order, but not enough to cover this hole, and we Texans are going to be seeing some fancy two-stepping over the next two years.

The one issue to raise income that seems to be getting a lot of trial balloons (based on multiple phone polls I have received, and some local paper articles) is an expansion of gambling. The lottery is showing declining revenue, and there is even one legislator who proposed abolishing it despite the loss in revenue, but there seems to be jockeying for everything from full-blown casinos in many of the larger cities to allowing slots at the few race tracks that have survived many years of indifferent attendance. There is even faint hope the legislature may permit the Native American tribes back into the games the attorney general shut down a few years ago - even in spite of certain creative lobbying efforts that led to other scandals but no progress for the tribes in the Piney Woods and El Paso areas. Even with these possibilities, and the hope to bring back revenue flowing out to state-line casinos in Oklahoma (One near Dallas claims to be the third-largest in the world now), Louisiana and New Mexico, there is not $20 billion to be found there. I would suspect a few prime pieces of public parkland, sponsorships for the public restrooms left on the highways (many already closed and razed recently) and other public gems may be available via online bidding sites before September, where the real fun begins with the new fiscal year. We all hope the new "lege" finds time between their planned Arizona-style immigration rants and Voter ID bills to look at the numbers and to put real effort into adult, balanced conversations that are not partisan but are proactive. If you believe this will happen with the "Super-majority" of GOP and Tea Partiers we have taking office, I have a bridge to nowhere for sale that can be yours for the price of only $10 billion.

One of the more peculiar phenomena in the current Recession has been the persistent drop in the Civilian Labor Force Participation Rate, after averaging around 64.5% for the past 20 years, in the past 18 months it has plunged, and despite a marginal improvement over the past several months, is still at 63.2%. This is counterintuitive when one analyzes the data side by side with the overall civilian population in the United States. An indexed chart, using the January 2000 level as a baseline demonstrates that while the US population has been climbing at a fairly steady arithmetic growth rate, the civilian labor force, which should track the changes in the actual population, has been behaving in an erratic pattern, having more to do with BLS data interpretation and the nuances of the business cycle than demographics. Which is why when reindexing data for nominal changes in the US rate of population growth, yields some troubling variations from the just disclosed 9.9% unemployment rate. Basing the adjustment to the unemployment rate on nothing but a statistical regression to the growth of America over the past ten years, would yield an unemployment rate of 15.7%. More troubling is that the underemployment rate would be a number far higher than the 17.6% disclosed for August 2010. According to our calculations, a reading closer to 23% would be more appropriate to represent the level of real joblessness in the US.
The reason why unemployment is and will be the scourge of the propaganda machine, is that while banks may provide mortgages to individuals with below average incomes and other potential black marks, this time around, having a job will be necessary. If we are right, and if indeed almost 34-some million people have at best recourse to the occasional temp worker paycheck, this will wreak havoc with the first derivative for the US "tail wags dog" economy where housing, and untenable and enslaving housing debt more specifically, is the critical support pillar of the ponzi scheme.
